title: Celtics reportedly trade Anfernee Simons to Bulls, acquire Nikola Vučević
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Celtics traded Anfernee Simons and a second-round pick to Bulls for Nikola Vučević and a second-round pick.
Trade reduces Celtics' luxury tax from $39.5 million to $17.7 million, putting them under the first tax apron.
Vučević, earning $21.5 million, averaged 16.9 points and 9.0 rebounds with Chicago this season.

title: What Mike Vrabel said of Robert Kraft’s latest snub from Pro Football Hall of Fame
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Patriots owner Robert Kraft was not voted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame Class of 2026.
Mike Vrabel expressed disappointment but believes Robert Kraft is deserving of Hall of Fame induction.
Robert Kraft has led the Patriots to six Super Bowl wins and 23 playoff appearances as owner.

title: Families of Revere women who died in Belize hotel file wrongful death lawsuit against resort, Expedia
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Three Revere women died of carbon monoxide poisoning at the Royal Kahal Beach Resort in Belize in February 2025.
Families filed a wrongful death lawsuit in Boston, seeking $100 million in damages from the resort, Expedia, and others.
The lawsuit claims the hotel ignored prior carbon monoxide warnings and lacked a functional detector in the suite.

title: She’s running Boston to raise money for Homes For Our Troops
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Rebecca Ludwig, 34, from DeKalb County, GA, is running the 2026 Boston Marathon for Homes For Our Troops.
Homes For Our Troops builds mortgage-free, adapted homes for severely injured veterans, promoting independence and stability.
Donations contribute to features like wheelchair-accessible layouts, roll-in showers, and pro-bono financial planning support.

title: Lawmakers urge Healey to  prepare for possible state prosecutions of federal officials
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Massachusetts senators urged Governor Maura Healey to establish a task force for potential state prosecutions of federal officials.
The proposal follows incidents involving federal agents' use of excessive force and wrongful actions in Minnesota and other areas.
Governor Healey recently enacted measures to restrict ICE operations in Massachusetts, including barring ICE in schools and hospitals.

title: She’s running Boston to honor her sister — and the hospital that treated her
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Hannah Orzechowski Murray, 31, from Malden, will run the 2026 Boston Marathon on the Dana-Farber team.
She is running in memory of her sister Grace, who died of glioblastoma at age 24 after treatment at Dana-Farber.
Murray's participation honors her sister, her family, and supports cancer awareness and Dana-Farber's care.

title: Advocates, officials welcome judge’s move to block end of protections for Haitian immigrants
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Judge Ana Reyes blocked the Trump administration from ending Temporary Protected Status for over 350,000 Haitian immigrants in the U.S.
The decision prevents job losses for Haitians in vital roles such as healthcare, impacting sectors in Massachusetts as noted by Gov. Maura Healey.
Legal experts warn the ruling is temporary, with potential appeals and uncertainties pending further judicial review.

title: What Robert Spillane and Harold Landry said about their injury statuses
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Harold Landry missed the AFC Championship due to a knee injury but anticipates playing in the Super Bowl.
Robert Spillane, returning from an ankle injury, is also planning to play in the Super Bowl after limited recent practice.
Both Landry and Spillane are listed as questionable for the Super Bowl and did not practice last week.

title: Hundreds of apartments proposed for former Weylu’s site
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Developers propose a 300-unit rental complex on former Weylu's site in Saugus, facing potential zoning challenges.
Saugus's 11.22% affordable housing eligibility for Safe Harbor could block the project, according to local officials.
The proposal includes four buildings on 7.28 acres, with resident concerns about traffic and blasting effects.

title: Ski Etiquette 101: What are your top do’s and don’ts for skiers and riders?
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Skiers should follow the National Ski Areas Association's 10-point safety guide for responsible skiing and riding.
Vermont mandates lowering chairlift bars, unlike other states, prompting mixed reactions from skiers and riders.
Social media complaints highlight issues like littering, smoking, and monopolizing space in ski lodges.
